title: Secret feature‚ù£ Xamarin Forms control's auto registration
Creating a good Xamarin Forms control - Part 3 - UI Day 4
In
the previous article
a
https://medium.com/@bigoudi/creating-a-good-xamarin-forms-control-part-2-ui-day-3-688bd0b3333d
I proposed the foundations of a win-win architecture for a good Xamarin Forms control using a multi targeting project.
Today I am presenting a way to create a control with a renderer that auto register itself, greatly simplifying the control's usage in teams, but also its documentation and its maintenance.
Before we start, a quick summary of the previous article

A multi-targeting project generates one library for each target platform (iOS, Android, ...), as if you were compiling the project for each individual platform. It is NOT a "shared project", but it contains the source code for every platform it supports. It has the
MSBuildSdkExtras
a
https://github.com/novotnyllc/MSBuildSdkExtras
SDK type.

For Xamarin Forms projects, you only need to add a reference to this multi-targeting project from your netstandard project. References are transitive and the Xamarin Forms platform projects will automatically reference the matching platform library.
novotnyllc/MSBuildSdkExtras
description: This package contains a few extra extensions to the SDK-style projects that are currently not available in Microsoft.NET.Sdk SDK. This feature is tracked in dotnet/sdk#491 The primary goal of this project is to enable multi-targeting without you having to enter in tons of properties within your csproj, vbproj, fsproj, thus keeping it nice and clean.

title: I'm gonna show you 2 ways to registrer a renderer: the official and the secret way. First the official way.
A "forms" control is a class with properties and events that can be used in XAML code. For example the Label.cs class that you use in XAML like this: <Label />.

This control class is shared on all platforms (android, ios, ...). Obviously it contains only codes that can be common to all platforms. Natively, on iOS for example, it is mapped to a UILabel from UIKit. On Android its a TextView from the Android SDK.
Each mapping must be declared to the Xamarin Forms runtime. This can be done in 2 way: the official way and the secret way.
For both ways you need a class called a
custom renderer
i
, which often inherits from the platform's UI control (UILabel for iOS) and an interface. A helper class ViewRenderer<Xaml,Platform>  implements the interface and can be used directly.
This can be done in 2 way: the official way and the secret way.
b
The official way to map a custom renderer to a xaml control is to add metadata to the assembly containing the renderer:
‚ö†This line have to lie outside any namespace declaration, otherwise the C# compiler silently ignores it.
When your app calls Forms.Init(), it will scan for this metadata in all
loaded
b
assemblies. In .NET apps assemblies are loaded on demand, as soon as a method contained in this assembly is called.
There is little chance that the assembly containing your custom renderer will be loaded between the app's entry point and the Forms.Init() call.

As a consequence, most of the existing Forms control libraries out in the wild requires you to initialize them by calling a static init method (like SvgImageRenderer.Init()) before calling Forms.Init() in each platform's project. And often this dummy static method is empty.

Yes there is a secret: you can bypass this call to Init(). Internally, Xamarin Forms maintains a dictionary of mappings from a xaml control (ex: SvgImage) to a custom renderer (ex: (SvgImageRenderer). This mapping is built by Forms.Init() ... but is mutable !
You add a custom renderer mapping at runtime by calling:
In older versions of Xamarin Forms, this method was available only on Android. Recent versions of Forms make it available on all platforms !
Don't forget the goal : simplify the usage of your custom control as much as possible to list the barriers that may block developers from using it. You really don't want any call to an Init() method!
So the question that remains is: can we call this register method automatically ? The answer is yes!
T
he question is: can we call this register method automatically ? The answer is yes!
b
For this trick to work, you need to have setup the project containing the custom control as a multi targeting project, like explained in
the previous article
a
https://medium.com/@bigoudi/creating-a-good-xamarin-forms-control-part-2-ui-day-3-688bd0b3333d
The idea is to register the renderer the first time the xaml class is used by xamarin forms. Yes it works !
The implementation uses a static boolean to detect if we already made the call to register, and a call to the register method in each underlying platform class. I created for you the
ControlDeclarationHelper
i
class. Simply add this line to your xaml's control's constructor:

The ControlDeclarationHelper class is straightforward but in 2 parts (it is a partial class). The first part is below. NETSTANDARD is automatically defined by the muti-targeting project (see previous article). It is required for the compilation to succeed, but is really defined in each platform version of our library. Thus the partial keyword.
